Consider a function \\( z(t) = x(t) + i y(t) \\) in which \\( x(t) \\) and \\( y(t) \\) are real functions representing a trajectory in the complex plane. We are given that the trajectory evolves according to the differential equation \\( \\dot{z} = Az \\) where A is a complex constant. We also consider the transformation defined by \\( g(z) = e^{Bt}z \\) where B is another complex constant.

If \\( g(z) \\) is applied to an initial point \\( z_0 \\) at \\( t = 0 \\), and then allowed to evolve under \\( \\dot{z} = Az \\) without further intervention, will \\( z(t) \\) at \\( t = T \\) be the same as if \\( z_0 \\) was directly evolved to \\( t = T \\) under \\( \\dot{z} = Az \\)?
Explanation: The application of \\( g(z) \\) modifies the initial state \\( z_0 \\) to \\( e^{B0}z_0 = z_0 \\), but the ongoing influence of \\( e^{Bt} \\) continuously changes the trajectory from what would have been under only \\( \\dot{z} = Az \\), leading to a position at \\( t = T \\) that depends on both A and B.
